title: Mortgage Renewal in 2026: What Every Canadian Needs to Know
description: Complete guide to renewing your mortgage in Canada in 2026. Payment shock calculations, fixed vs variable rates, switching lenders, penalty math, and strategies to prepare.
author: Rick Minji
excerpt: Roughly 1.2 million Canadian mortgages are up for renewal in 2026, and most borrowers face rates 2-3 percentage points higher than what they're paying. A $500K mortgage going from 1.89% to 4.5% means ~$700/month more. Here's how to prepare, negotiate, and minimize the impact.

title: What Canadians Get Wrong About Capital Gains Tax (2026 Update)
description: Comprehensive guide to Canadian capital gains tax in 2026. The new inclusion rate, principal residence exemption, LCGE, worked examples, and strategies to minimize your tax bill.
author: Rick Minji
excerpt: The 2024 capital gains inclusion rate change confused a lot of Canadians. Here's what actually changed: individuals pay 50% inclusion on the first $250K of gains per year and 66.67% above that. We bust the myths, run worked examples, and show you how to legally minimize what you owe.

title: The True Cost of Raising a Child in Canada (2026 Edition)
description: Complete breakdown of raising a child in Canada from birth to 18. Includes provincial costs, CCB benefits, RESP strategies, and real cost estimates by age bracket.
author: Rick Minji
excerpt: Raising a child from birth to age 18 in Canada costs approximately $293,000 to $350,000, depending on your province and lifestyle choices. However, with the Canada Child Benefit (CCB) providing up to $180,000 over 18 years and smart RESP contributions capturing $7,200 in free government money, the net cost ranges from $113,000 to $170,000.

title: How Much Do You Really Need to Retire in Canada? The 2026 Numbers
description: Comprehensive guide to retirement savings in Canada for 2026. Learn about CPP, OAS, GIS, provincial cost differences, and how much you need for modest, comfortable, or affluent retirement.
author: Rick Minji
excerpt: Most Canadians will need between $400,000 and $1.2 million in retirement savings (excluding their home) to maintain their lifestyle, depending on their province and spending level. When combined with CPP and OAS, this translates to a retirement income ranging from $35,000 to $80,000+ annually.

title: FHSA vs RRSP for Your First Home: Which Should You Max Out First?
description: Comparing FHSA ($8K/year, $40K lifetime) vs RRSP HBP ($60K withdrawal) for first-time home buyers. Worked examples at $50K, $80K, $120K income with decision flowchart and optimal strategies.
author: Rick Minji
excerpt: Choosing between maxing your FHSA or RRSP for your first home down payment can save you thousands. We compare contribution limits ($8K vs $40K lifetime), tax treatment, repayment rules, and show worked examples at three income levels to help you decide which account to prioritize.

title: RRSP vs TFSA in 2026: Which Should Canadians Max Out First?
description: Discover whether to prioritize RRSP or TFSA contributions in 2026. Compare contribution limits, tax benefits, and income-based strategies to maximize your Canadian retirement savings.
author: Rick Minji
excerpt: Choosing between maximizing your RRSP or TFSA is one of the most common financial dilemmas facing Canadians. Both are powerful savings vehicles, but they work very differently—and the right choice depends heavily on your current income, future plans, and financial goals.

title: 2026 Canadian Tax Brackets Explained: Federal + Every Province
description: Complete 2026 Canadian tax brackets guide covering federal rates plus all 10 provinces and 3 territories. Includes CPP2 changes, basic personal amounts, and tax planning strategies.
author: Rick Minji
excerpt: Understanding Canadian tax brackets is essential for effective tax planning. In 2026, federal and provincial tax rates continue to evolve, with CPP2 enhancements and indexed basic personal amounts affecting your take-home pay.

title: First-Time Home Buyer's Guide to Canada in 2026
description: Complete 2026 guide for Canadian first-time home buyers. Learn about FHSA, HBP, down payment strategies, CMHC insurance, stress test rules, and provincial rebates to buy your first home.
author: Rick Minji
excerpt: Buying your first home in Canada can feel overwhelming, but 2026 brings several helpful programs including the First Home Savings Account (FHSA), enhanced Home Buyers' Plan, and provincial incentives that can make homeownership more accessible.

title: Avalanche vs Snowball: The Best Debt Payoff Strategy for Canadians
description: Avalanche vs Snowball debt payoff methods explained for Canadians. Learn which strategy works best for student loans, credit cards, and LOCs in 2026's interest rate environment.
author: Rick Minji
excerpt: When you're carrying multiple debts—credit cards, student loans, car payments, lines of credit—choosing the right payoff strategy can save you thousands in interest and help you become debt-free faster. The two most popular approaches are the Avalanche and Snowball methods.

title: How to Value a Small Business in Canada: A Practical Guide
description: Learn how to value a small business in Canada using DCF, comparable multiples, and asset-based methods. Includes industry rules of thumb, goodwill calculations, and CRA tax implications.
author: Rick Minji
excerpt: Whether you're buying, selling, or seeking funding for a small business in Canada, understanding valuation is critical. Business valuation combines art and science—blending financial analysis with industry knowledge and market conditions.
